content:
Many thanks for referring [redacted name] who I met today with her husband and daughter. She is a 62 year old lady who has unfortunately been diagnosed with small cell carcinoma of the pancreatic tail with bone metastases.?
?
Her symptoms began approximately 3 months ago with progressive upper abdominal pain radiating to her back, associated with significant weight loss of 12kg and increasing fatigue. She initially presented to her GP with these symptoms and was referred for an ultrasound scan which showed a pancreatic mass. Subsequent CT demonstrated a 6.8cm mass in the tail of pancreas with multiple bone metastases affecting the thoracic spine, ribs, and pelvis. A CT-guided biopsy on 15 March 2024 confirmed small cell carcinoma with strong CD56 positivity.?
?
She has experienced a significant decline in her mobility over the past month due to bone pain, particularly affecting T8 vertebra, and now requires a wheelchair for anything more than short distances. Her performance status has deteriorated from 1 to 3 over this period. She is managing oral intake but describes early satiety and occasional nausea.?
?
In her past medical history, she has well-controlled type 2 diabetes on metformin, and hypothyroidism on levothyroxine. She had a previous cholecystectomy in 2015. She has never smoked and drinks minimal alcohol.?
?
She lives with her husband who has taken time off work to help care for her. Her daughter lives nearby and provides additional support. She worked as a primary school teacher but has been unable to work for the past 2 months due to her symptoms.?
?
On examination today, she appears cachectic with marked muscle wasting. There is tenderness in the left upper quadrant with a palpable mass. Spinal examination reveals point tenderness over T8. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits but she has reduced mobility due to pain.?
?
I have discussed her case in detail with our team. Given the aggressive nature of small cell carcinoma and her deteriorating performance status, we recommend urgent commencement of combination chemotherapy with carboplatin and etoposide. I have explained the aims of treatment are to improve her symptoms and hopefully extend her life, though we cannot cure the cancer. We have discussed common side effects including fatigue, nausea, risk of neutropenic sepsis, and hair loss.?
?
We have arranged urgent MRI spine to fully assess the thoracic vertebral metastases and will consider palliative radiotherapy depending on findings. She has been started on regular oxycodone for pain control with immediate effect.?
?
She will be admitted to our ward tomorrow to commence chemotherapy, allowing close monitoring of her condition and response to treatment. Our palliative care team will review her during admission to optimize symptom control.?
